title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify court jurisdiction for issuing warrants. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify court jurisdiction for issuing warrants, including State court procedures. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify court jurisdiction for issuing warrants, including State court procedures. The amendment expands the definition of courts that can issue warrants to include any district court of the United States or any United States court of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated. The jurisdiction for issuing warrants is expanded to include any district court of the United States or any United States court of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated. The jurisdiction for issuing warrants is expanded to include any district court of the United States or any United States court of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated. This includes courts authorized by the law of the State to issue search warrants. The jurisdiction for issuing warrants is expanded to include any district court of the United States or any United States court of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated, including courts authorized by the law of the State to issue search warrants. Foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions can be executed upon application by a Federal judge, as authorized by the Department of Justice, to assist foreign authorities in investigating or prosecuting criminal offenses. The Federal judge can issue orders for assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions, including search warrants and warrants for electronic communications. The Federal judge can issue orders for wire or electronic communications, pen registers, trap and trace devices, and testimony or document production in criminal investigations or prosecutions. A Federal judge may appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents in response to a request from a foreign authority. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders for appearance or document production. A Federal judge may appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents in response to a request from a foreign authority. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders for appearance or document production, administer oaths, and receive documents or statements. Requests can be filed in the district where the person resides or where the documents are located. The Federal judge may appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony or production of documents in response to a foreign authority's request. The appointed person can issue orders for appearance or document production, administer oaths, and receive documents or statements. Requests can be filed in the district where the person resides, where the documents are located, or in a district related to a Federal criminal investigation or prosecution. An application for a search warrant from a foreign authority must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. A Federal judge can issue a search warrant only if the foreign offense involves conduct punishable by imprisonment in the United States. The text discusses the conditions under which an order or warrant issued by a foreign authority can be served in the United States. It also clarifies that foreign authorities or interested parties can seek assistance in criminal investigations under certain provisions. Section 1782 of title 28, United States Code defines key terms such as 'Federal judge' and 'foreign authority' for the purposes of criminal proceedings. Section 1782 of title 28, United States Code defines key terms for criminal proceedings, including 'Federal judge' and 'foreign authority'. The amendment adds provisions for designated authorities to request assistance in criminal matters from the United States. Foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions are addressed in section 3512.
